annotation.TEXT: Tune Woman herself is relatively easy to deal with in terms of patterns. She'll periodically emerge from the stage in one of a few set locations, then run around and occasionally fire a swaying projectile. The spotlights/darkness effect can actually get in your way at times however, especially if she fires one of these projectiles from the other end of the screen, leaving the darkness to cover up its path and you guessing as to where it is.

Cipher Decode serves roughly the same purpose as Jolt Shocker, but in a different way. Whenever it hits something, it slows down to linger on the enemy while dealing out damage. While it's decent enough for dealing with things like Sniper Joes, it also eats through ammo reserves every time it deals damage to something. Personally, I prefer Jolt Shocker over this.

This part of the stage is the only one I have any issues with. The lights in this area will periodically go dark, leaving you to memorize the layout lest you jump blindly to your death. I'm not exactly against this gimmick, mind you. Shovel Knight practically did the same thing with Specter Knight's stage - but at least there, the lightning effects were fast. Here, I feel the room stays dark for a bit longer than necessary.

A special note on these chameleon enemies: I could be mistaken, but I think these are the only two instances of this particular enemy in the game. They don't seem to show up anywhere else aside from this one room.

Scorch Flame isn't quite as bad as Tune Note, but it's still not that great. Using it at first activates an aura of fire around Mega Man, and pressing the fire button again launches out large flame projectiles on both sides. It's certainly an interesting weapon concept, but aside from weakness affiliations (and puzzles), it doesn't deal enough damage to most enemies.

Despite how bad Tune Note is, I'd still recommend picking it up before fighting Scorch Man. This fight can be downright nasty at times, if mainly due to how frequently he can launch out his projectiles. He also has two types of dashing attacks: One where he leaves trails of flames on the ground, and another that actively tracks your movements. Just hope that he doesn't get into the habit of abusing these, because he's completely invincible during them.

Tune Note is easily the worst weapon in the game. It's slow, it goes in a wavy pattern, and its damage output is the equivalent to a single uncharged buster pellet. Aside from weakness affiliations, this thing isn't leaving the bench for the rest of this run.

Cipher Man himself isn't too difficult, but the fight can quickly turn annoying depending on which moves he uses. Specifically, his shield move that requires you to match up numbers in order to get rid of it. He can easily spam this multiple times in rapid succession during the fight (as seen here). Thankfully, his actions are greatly slowed down once he has his shield up, giving you a slightly easier time in matching up the numbers.

Just to note: You can actually get behind this mini-boss to avoid all of its attacks. However, you'll still have to jump periodically to avoid it as it backs up slightly. The timing on it is pretty strict though, so I wouldn't recommend doing it.

As you can probably tell by now, this stage's main gimmicks involve lighting effects and springs. Thankfully, the combination of the two isn't quite as evil as it could be. Although there is one particular section that does manage to introduce some problems, but for a different reason...

The "Punk Needles" essentially act like a faster version of Screw Crusher, only it spits out a bunch of projectiles in the process. While it seems like a decent upgrade, its damage output is roughly the same as a single buster shot. Plus, the main portion of the projectile goes away after hitting something. It is kind of fun to spam it and flood the screen with needles, but its ammo drains so fast in the process that it's barely worth using even for that.

The challenge rooms are short, but with that being said, they're not without their issues. This first one introduces exploding blocks (which can potentially bring out some uncomfortable memories of those found in Trinitro Man's stage). These blocks are directly over a pit, and there are a few flying enemies positioned in just the right spot to knock you back and kill you instantly. Safe to say, this is the most evil of the four rooms.

Time for the second Mega Man Killer. Punk is downright brutal in this game - mainly because his speed has been increased tremendously. Fortunately, there's actually a bit of a rhythm you can get into with this fight. Syncing up with his Screw Crusher tosses and dashes isn't easy, but once you get it down, it makes this fight far more manageable than what it first appears.

Illusion Man is in the same boat as Cipher Man. The fight can either remain simple or become annoying depending on which moves he uses. He can spawn clones of himself (which thankfully don't deal contact damage), along with increasing his size in an attempt to stomp on you (he's also invincible during this attack). If he decides not to spam these moves however, you can beat him fairly easily with the Cipher Decode - though it can get caught up on Illusion Man's own projectiles.
Alas, it seems I have now made the rare Lava Tortoise extinct. Much like the chameleons from Illusion Man's stage, that particular enemy doesn't appear anywhere else in the game.

Illusion Blast doesn't have as much power behind it as some of the other weapons (it only seems to deal the equivalent of one buster pellet), but its homing ability and firing rate more than makes up for it. I'd actually go as far as to say it's one of the most important weapons in the game (if mainly for dealing with certain enemies).

Normally Primal Man would be next up in the weakness chain, but I honestly want to hold off on dealing with his stage for now (at least until I get a particular weapon). As such, we're taking a detour to Tune Woman. Her weapon isn't anything spectacular, but I still want it in preparation for a different fight.

Continuing with the weakness chain, Cipher Man is up next. Incidentally, this is also one of the shortest stages in the game. It primarily consists of four challenge rooms (similar to Sword Man's stage, although these ones don't require you to use weapons), and after which it's immediately off to the boss.

I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one to point this out by now, but the first instance of disappearing blocks is introduced directly over a pit. I know this game is intended to be for fans of the original series and all, but still - if some of the other gimmicks were introduced in safe environments, why not these?
